author: AnDom

description.text: This is a junk box.
It's a castle!
I first made the walls.Then the central area.I made the drawbridge last.

This guide helps keep your two filament tubes and wiring going to the hot end organized. This should also help the wiring bend along the full radius of its length instead of just by the head. This guide will work on a Flashforge Creator pro and probably on the Replicator and Replicator 2X, although the clips are sized for the Creator Pro specifically.

2015-21-07: Added fillets to all sides of the 3D model, this allows easier removal from the build plate when printing without raft. Added Bi Clip Guide version for single extruder setups.

Print, peel off build plate, hook over wire loom, snap in filament tube(s).

Suggested print profile: Low settings, no raft, no supports. Smaller clip inside diameter is made to snap over the filament tube provide with flash forge machines.

description.text:
This is my first draft for the make it float contest #makeitfloat

1st iteration- problem getting it to stay on my printer, reworked base
2nd iteration- too shallow
3rd iteration- problem printing due to volume; paddle very thick (3mm)
4th iteration- made base into 2 pieces, separated "cabin" and coin holders; Paddle too thin (1.5mm) and too long

Final iteration- Boat is in five pieces, new paddle

This thing requires gluing with acetone or superglue. The front must be attached to the back. A rubber band (or hair tie) is also needed to attach the paddle to the stern. The coin holder can be removed at any time as well as the cabin.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1CDjdz3TXVK

This is a 1:24 (1/2"=1'-0") scale version of a High End Systems Cyberlight.

Help with my next creation!
I decided that my fish needed a puddle jumper to play in so I threw this together over the course of about an hour. Its sized to fit in my Stargate (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:927206) and I think I will expand the detail as time goes on for more of a display model, but as I said this one is intended for my fish :) Because of that there is no internal detail, no detail in the bottom or back and there are 3 vents in the end so that the water does not get stagnant inside. Keep an eye out for the more detailed version including extended drive pods!

Update
The file labelled update is NOT intended for printing. It is to keep you apprised with where I am on the current state of the detailed model. If you want to you can print the parts and see if they fit but its not done yet!
Shell0.8 is the one I printed for the fish.

title: Remix of Mostly Printed CNC -Add On- LEG

description.text:
Update 2/24/2016
I made this parametric so you could adjust some of the dimensions. I also made a version for the base like the update from Allted. I made this for the U.S. Version initially, but made the openscad files so you can easily change it to the IE version, by adjusting these 2 variables. I have not printed this new version yet, so if you use this, print 1 1st to test how it works for you. The IE versions of the STL file have an IE_ prefix in the name.
Cyl_ID = 23.7; //IE version used 25
Cyl_OD = 35.7; //IE version used 37

This is a remix of the addon leg to compensate for either slightly different Outside Diameter of pipe or slightly different tolerance in printing this. I had to sand the inside diameter of the original part that was 23.5mm. 23.7mm worked perfectly for me with no sanding.

I included an openscad source file to facilitate making different Inside Diameter of this part. Either print Flex_FootRemix_23_7mmID_rev2_repaired.stl or edit the openscad file & change the ID variable to the size you want. The Flex_Foot.STL file is the original part & referenced by the openscad file.

The rest of the instructions follow from the original part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902483

author: GeoDave

description.text:
EATS THE COFFEE,...not the foil lid :O

This thing is for extracting the coffee grounds out of used k-cups for composting, as coffee grounds make excellent fertilizer (and cost a lot to individually package so why not reuse them??? : )

You will need a "wide mouth" style mason jar, then just add the spent coffee grounds to your compost when the jar fills up, as you can see in the picture, a little bit each day adds up!

This edition uses like 12 grams less plastic than previous editions so it prints waaaaaaay faster...

I've included the necessary supports with central raft so you don't have to wonder if the central supports will break off the build plate, (and don't need to waste plastic printing a full-size raft under the entire part)

My duplicator 4 will print one in about 36 minutes at .4 resolution with a fan, if you don't use a fan it may start to twist the tip a bit, but will work.

If printing straight on aluminum, turn on fan prior to first layer of printing, I use a 12V computer fan with a 9V adapter, aluminium build plate at 80C no glue, no blue tape...the secret technique I've discovered that works for sub-2h prints is that the PLA sticks to the build plate at 80C, after the print is done, just wait about 8 minutes for the build plate to cool down below 42C, and the print naturally contracts then pops off the build plate with no effort...
Over 2h prints, use blue tape at 80C, then when the print is finished, "preheat" the build plate to 110C and use a thin sheet of metal to spatula up the plastic part from the blue tape and set the whole thing on a sheet of glass to cool (like a cookie)

like the 2 derivative of rev41 68mm edition 'force' scaled,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:929489

and rev49 for 68mm
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:934185
nice work : )

first release: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:711329

Feel free to contact me with ideas/suggestions post pictures of your builds!!!

: )

peace.

description.text: Edition 2 of the keyslink design. I prefer this one since its very minimal and much easier to carry around. also prints faster and uses less filament. Requires furter modification of keys but if you're not afraid of a dremel (or any rotary tool) then this should be a piece of cake.

print the main case vertically to avoid supports and to increase accuracy. I recommend printing on fine setting of your printer supports it. print the back and then make 2 extra copies of the key driver and print it with the thumb part flat on the bed for accuracy. cut key to a height of 10 - 12 mm and use the driver to trace an outline on the key (see picture above for how it should be positioned and oriented). cut the grooves and attach it to the key and slide it into the case from the back. place the cover onto the back and (optional) secure it with epoxy.

200mm x 200mm optical breadboard with M6 and M3 holes, Metric Standard 25mm and 12.5mm apart. 3D printable with M6 and M3 nuts inserts. Use Cura with the ''Pause at Height'' plugin to set the printer to pause at 8.55mm height, move the nozzle out of the way with the software (not with your hand), insert the nuts in their holes, skirt a bit of filament and press play. Or you can find the layer height in the G-code and insert a Pause command line there.
OK now, one of the models has so many screw holes is probably overkill and will affect the structural integrity of the breadboard so I made another one with less M3 holes.
Recommended settings: Set the vertical walls to minimum 2 pass thickness; Set the horizontal walls to about 1mm thick; Set the infill to about 15-20%
Download the SketchUp model attached to customize and adjust your tolerances, this one was optimized for the machine we have in our lab.

author: GeoDave

title: Dremel jig for putting holes in bottle caps

description.text:
If you want to put a hole in a bottle cap and don't have a bit large enough, but have a Dremel with a 561 Multipurpose bit, this offset jig will make it easier to get a (mostly) round hole.

Fusion 360 file sketch dimensions can be changed to adjust for bottle cap diameter and desired hole diameter.

FYI: the Dremel collar is a 3/4" 12 TPI UN thread.

Update: the F3D file is slightly improved to handle parameterization better.

Start the bit at an angle to the top to make an access hole without the jig in place. Screw jig onto Dremel collar, place bit in the hole, then using the outer ring as a guide, slowly rotate the cap around. It helps to use both hands.

title: HatchBox spool holder for FlashForge Creator Pro,  and some other Replicator 2X clones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I recently bought a FlashForge Creator Pro to use for rapid prototyping at work and discovered that the included filament spoolholders were way too large in diameter to accommodate my stockpile of Hatchbox filament spools. Unlike other designs here on Thingiverse, this one was patterned after the original.

Modeled in DesignSpark Mechanical in just a few minutes.

Two pieces to make it super easy to print. Weld together with acetone.

Update: I now have a version for Taulman 3D 1lb filament spools also. I will publish it soon.

Print both pieces in ABS. File slot as required to allow tang to be inserted into the main part. (this will vary depending on your printer)

Apply acetone with an small artists brush to weld the parts together.

comments.text: Thanks for this prototype.  I found that the NEW Hatchbox spools are too big for this design... back to the drawing board!
comments.author: pifern14

comments.text: Thank you for this. I'm new to printing and ordered several rolls of filament. When it arrived, oops.. it doesn't fit. Came across this and this morning I'm able to print using all my filament. Great!

This spool holder is designed to fit the Robo 3DR1 printer. After trying other top mount designs that either vibrate loose or require additional hardware to assemble, this design uses an interlocking assembly to insure the spool hub will not loosen due to vibrations.

Spool hubs included fit 1" and 2.5" wide filament spools. If you use spools of a different width, drop me a note and I will modify the width of the spool hub for your needs.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Glass corner clip

description.text:
NOTE: This version suffers from heat deformation over time, and always loosens up after a few of my prints. I've designed a better version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1291106

Based on the Makersome clip, this version removes the beveled inset, and lowers the height a little bit. I made this to fit a glass plate with PEI bed material having a combined thickness of 3.5 mm. The height sits slightly lower than the surface, but above the glass. Since the inset is removed, it will work with plates as large as the bed size, and a little bigger. Please note that this does not apply any downward pressure on the plate. It is only holding it in place.

Make sure you use lock washers (size #6 worked for me). I noticed that after a while, the nut loosens up, and my glass plate was given an opportunity to slide around a little.

author: LukeBox

description.text:
A school project with Miss Fukano in Toyo institute of Art.

You can buy finished product from here (Japan only, sorry).
https://minne.com/items/2342738

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing.

Layer pitch is 0.3mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

120 minutes to print. 30 minutes for shaping and constructing.
13m for ABS.

Other parts,
2 pins (ø3*6, SUS)

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.
However you have to tap holes, you can not make loose screw or you can not joint objects face by face because it needs driver.

note. You need "reamer" and "drill chuck" to adjust holes.

description.text:
This is an entry for the #MakeItFloat competition.

The design consist of four separate canisters intended to hold
Australian $1 coins this allows a person to experiment with the
vessel's ballast by placing various amounts of coins in each canister until the vessel ultimately sinks.

Our record was $30 in $1 coins.

We used Rhino to model the various parts of the vessel and then used a the Makerbot Replicator 2 at RBA's office - https://www.thingiverse.com/rba/about - who we wish to thank very much.

We found the easiest way to print was through the default settings, and printing 2 canisters at a time just in case the print went bad.

As a final note we'd liked to ask you to come up with more inventive ways of utilising this design than just carrying coins. We are currently working on using it as a floating planter for wheatgrass - we like to stay healthy.

description.text: Ball in cube by Mia
Ball in cube by Mia designed in Tinkercad. Infill 10%, 2 shells, .3 Layer Height, raft and supports.

My wife likes her K810 bluetooth keyboard - but not its angle or the fact that it slides around the table... So a couple of hours with Rhino3D and here's a simple solution to blutack onto the bottom. (If you did not want it removable, you could use double sided tape)

This will surely also fit a range of small portable keyboards and make them more comfortable to use

Simple lofts using Rhino3D and some cutouts using a Grasshopper script I keep around that creates planar voronoi volumes in bounded spaces.

There are recesses for 12mm square rubber feet, which are available in any hobby electronics store...

p.s. sorry about the STL file size; I like fine meshes; it could be much simplified and look pretty much the same, but it really makes no difference given the amount of computer power in ouor hands these days...

title: DJI Inspire 1 broken case handle fix

description.text:
The case comes with DJI Inspire 1 is handy but poorly built. Both plastic piece that attaches the handle to the case broke on mine. They used some horribly injected brittle plastic with self tapping screws.

When you take the broken handle off, along with the broken part you will find a handle, two plastic gaskets(?) and a metal bar with slots. Discard the self tapping screws and the broken part.

I printed this upright, with PLA, 100% infill.

It is attached to the case with 30mm M3 socket head hex screws and M3 washers. On the nut side I drilled 3mm hole in 4 coins (pennies will work) to make extra large washers to secure the M3 nuts onto the M4 slots on metal bar.

comments.text: Thank you!!

description.text:
This is a piggy bank, and school project with Miss Tanno in Toyo institute of Art.

This time I tried to make a bayonet mount to lock cap like SLR camera lenses.

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing.

Layer pitch is 0.3mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

630 minutes to print. 60 minutes for shaping and constructing.
53m for ABS.

Other parts,
7 pins (ø26, SUS)
1 rod (ø220, SUS)

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.
However you have to tap holes, you can not make loose screw or you can not joint objects face by face because it needs driver.

note. You need "reamer" and "drill chuck" to adjust holes.

A school project with Miss Isobe in Toyo institute of Art.

This was my first try to use metal pins. And thanks to it, I could construct the model without any glue.

The bench swings smoothly, and I can take it apart easily to change colors.

You can buy finished product from here (Japan only, sorry).
https://minne.com/items/2344332

Newer version is here.
http://www.11moon.com/minne/Swing/Swing_202.zip

It is 1.2 times larger than before, and adjusted gaps for easier assembling.

Here is a movie to assemble it.
https://youtu.be/8S2so6Gw3-I

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing.

Layer pitch is 0.2mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness.

No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT).

240 minutes to print. 30 minutes for shaping and constructing.

Other parts,
2 pins (ø4*12, SUS)

How to use pins?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BNg1lNYXcFk

In case of traditional machining, making accurate pin-holes on object is not so easy thing,
especially if the object is small, has irregular shape or the pin-hole is angled.
Because it needs additional assembling jigs to fix.

However, in case of 3D printing, it is pretty easy.
It does not need any other cost, except adding holes in 3D data.

The metal pins are enough accurate, so you can make both type of holes lock and roose easily.
Also it is much more strong than 3D printing materials, so you can make thin strut or axle.
Also it is enough cheap so you can bury under objects, or glue it.

Of course you can use screws. Actually screws are more usual in real world.

title: Workbench Cable chain guide with mount to Workbench.

description.text:
Needed something that would fit in a tighter space and I liked this fpvgalaxy's design over most others.

I reduced the width of it to 30mm. I also redesigned the wire clip due to the shape not printing adequately.

Think I have completed this as much as I want to right now. Could use more tweaks here and there. but as this project sits it works great with fairly modest post print processing.

IF YOU PRINT!!! I suggest that you print with at least a 70% infill. Especially the mounts!

Currently printed in ABS!!! Suggest printing with NO rafts. You know your printer better than I, on mine though it prints more clean and with less after print processing!

Update: Created a clip on mount for the machine side of the drag chain. Next will be the extruder side.

Also changed the position of the clip. Reason the mechanics of the clip is more solid being printed on the side. The other way allowed the clip ends to break off easily.

I used the original stl. as a guide and rebuilt the ends from scratch, spit in half and then mirrored.

comments.text: GREAT WORK ON THE DESIGN!! I printed most of it except the dual extrusion base, is that base thinner from the original to reduce the height of the system?? because I mounted the chain mount on the extruder motors and it looks like it's higher than the frame so the cable system can't go into the left side of the frame of the work bench.

author: Nick_W

description.text:
This is another portable air conditioner prototype however this one uses an external source of coolant (as opposed to the first that used ice inside it). This model has cutouts for 4mm (or 6mm) diameter copper tubing to run inside in front of the airflow from a 120mm fan. the coolant source then can be whatever you want to be (most might use a cooler filled with ice water and a pump). You can also do the reverse and use a hot coolant source (like hot water) and use it as a heater instead.

There's an integrated handle and a rear standoff counterbalance (40mm) that'll support most any 120mm-sized fan.

Obviously, the pro is longer operational time depending on your coolant source (and less potential mess) at the con of having an external source.
You'll need fifteen ~4mm (or ~6mm/1/4" if printing the other version) diameter copper tubing cut around ~180mm each (the width of the model is 150mm). You'll also need a coolant source and 120mm fan.

Got a (sunhokey) Prusa i3 from china. But didn't come with a switch to turn off printer, So purchased a green 4Pin rocker switch and wired it in.
The one I printed out, I had to rivet the box onto the power supply as couldn't get the nuts in there. This version I printed in nut holders, so should fix problem (or just rivet it in like I did).

I think it will fit most Chinese power supplies.
measures - 110mm x 30mm x 40mm
Made with sketchup

description.text:
I've been meaning to make a simple airboat for several years, in fact when I was younger I tried to build one unfortunately I never got around the remote control part.

Bear in mind that this is still a work in progress.

20/07 - It works :-D. The direction mechanism needs some adjustments (fins, fins support, gear) to improve the turning radius, despite this it works rather well.

19/07 - Added revised versions for some of the parts. Some parts were a bit too flimsily and fixed some oversights. Currently printing the last part and assembling the airboat.

18/07 - Added a revised base version, should take less time to print and save a bit of filament. Also added support to the central arc.

I'm printing all of these parts with a E3D v6 with a .4 nozzle and PLA

You can get the propeller here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116974

Print it out and plump up the parts with a little foam.

Hexagon style shelves are not an uncommon diy project, the interwebs is flooded with them! So, after studying hundreds of hexagon projects I quickly noticed that mostly everyone was using a tool called a (sliding) compound miter saw. And you’ve guessed it, I don’t own or know anybody with this particular tool. So the challenge of this project was to make a hexagon shelf without the use of such a tool.

The idea

So basically a hexagon shelves consists out of six wooden boards with 60 degree edges on both sides. The idea is to 3D-print a mounting block that attaches to the sides of the board, this mounting block is shaped like a triangle so that the adjacent board is mounted at a 60 degree angle. The 3D print has 3 holes (ha! 3D!) in which a screw attaches the mounting block to the wooden board. This way there is no need for an expensive sliding compound miter saw, you just need an expensive 3D printer to do the job!

For more info on the hexagon shelves and other cool projects take a look at my website: http://www.fritsmakesstuff.com/hexagon-style-diy-shelves/

If you like making stuff such as the hexagon shelves; follow me on twitter to keep updated with similar projects: https://twitter.com/fritsmakesstuff

Printin'

Print the mounting blocks with 100% infill in the toughest material you have available. Be very critical towards the quality of the parts, in the end they will need to keep your stuff attached to the wall, and that being said, don't overload the shelves with lot's of stuff.

Paintin’ & Sandin’

I made the mistake in this project to cut the wooden boards first and paint them afterwards. Because I wanted to paint only one side of the board I used masking tape to prevent the edges of the board to be painted. Unfortunately, the paint always seemed to be creeping in between the board and the masking tape. This resulted in hours of sanding the edges that had paint on them, painting another layer and sanding all-over again. Next time I would paint an entire board with a couple of coats and then cut the wooden boards to size.

Assembly & Mounting

The hexagons are formed by attaching the mounting blocks to the sides of each board with the use of screws. I made three hexagons from which two were joined (and thus were sharing some of the mounting blocks). I used cardboard cut-outs to get a sense of how I wanted to position the hexagons in the space, eventually I decided to go with this composition and dotted out the necessary markings for drilling.
To mount everything to the wall I cut up an ‘L’-shape aluminum profile into pieces and drilled two holes for the screws that attach the hexagons to the wall.

description.text: Simple stand to keep your exercise ball from rolling around the house. Designed for a ball that's about 22" diameter but would probably work with just about any size.

This is a spool rack made of a broomstick and 3D printed legs.

you can find more details here:
http://harariprojects.com/2015/07/18/3d-printed-filament-rack/

and more projects of mine here:
http://harariprojects.com/

to create this you'll need a broomstick cut to length, two or more printed legs (more than two can be used for extra support in the case of a long rack with a lot of spools), two screws and two nuts.

the model fits a broomstick diameter of ~21.5mm. I provided the original file so that you can modify it as needed (created in sketchup)

you can find more information about this here:
http://harariprojects.com/2015/07/18/3d-printed-filament-rack/

description.text:
Hey guys,

(this is the positive version of my original negative)

When my motor blew last year i had some spare time on my hands, whilst waiting for my new motor and various parts, I made GT centre caps for my wheels!

I had alot of fun with this, had a mate saying it would just melt, but he has no idea on 3d printing, or materials, and its been 9months now...still going strong...PLA has held up against the heat, brake dust and the elements, they still look great.

Sketchup file is provided for those wishing to refine the design further, and adjusting size for your particular centre cap sizing..

I printed a couple out in glow in the dark filament too, just for fun, never actually installed them.

printed in PLA (stands up to the task well surprisingly)

dont remember the layer height, somewhere round the 200micron mark i believe.

secure to centre cap wit some form of RTV silicon, or sumthing alike.

title: (moved) Geared Follow Focus

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/geared-follow-focus Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html _____ After my gearless follow focus,
here a geared one.
Swapping the lens is not as easy as it is with the gearless one and you need a lens-gear for every lens but you also need no pressure to create friction.
The follow focus and lens gear are compatible with industry standard 0.8 pitch follow focus equipment.
The axis use 608 bearings to reduce any noise of threaded rods on plastic that could be picked up by the microphone and to make this run as smooth as possible.
The mounting is for an industry standard 15mm rail support system such as
my 3d printed shoulder rig: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7278 With a follow focus you have precise, manual control over the focus (or zoom) of your lens.
It is used for professional filming where precise control of the focus is required and where a pumping autofocus would simply ruin the take.
Commercial versions are sadly terribly expensive. :( Photos: https://picasaweb.google.com/Marcus.Wolschon/201105_201106_geared_follow_focus?feat=directlin
Blog post: http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/06/3d-printed-geared-follow-focus.html Video (Part I) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=imy2UaUzNeY Update: (2011-07-17)
Added lens_gear_version3 with a wider tap for the bolt.

The large part may not print on a Thing-o-Matic but require a printer with a larger build volume such as a RepMan or RepRap.

  • Use the hand-wheel from litwan, it works better then mine. :)

  • fit the gears with the bearings. Do not fit the bearings first then then try to insert the gears. It will not work and can be quite hard to remove the bearings to try again.

title: Rugged case for Sparkfun FTDI Basic Breakout

description.text:
A case for the Sparkfun FTDI basic breakout (either 5V or 3.3V), that is snug and rugged. Couldn't find one, so I made one.

Source available (albeit messy :), feel free to remix for other FTDI breakouts.

Update 8/17: Fixed LED hole positions (thanks, @mikegi).

You will need four 8mm M3 screws and nuts (or, if your printer tolerances are really tight, you can even try without). Nut hole tolerances are intended for press-fitting with soldering iron.

You may need to lightly file down the surfaces of the two halves that come into contact with each other (the CAD model has zero slack there). Also, don't forget to clear the single-layer supports in the screw holes.

UPDATE

Sorry for the delay! :) There is the version 2 of the animepples. I was hoping to get time to print them all and add them one by one once printed. But I have no time and thanks to a comment in the thing I have realized that.

So here it is, my second version for the agricola. I'm already working in the third version which would include the humans and the fences... but don't expect this soon. :)

Thank you guys!

My version of Agricola animepples. Created from a photo of animepples in the BoardGameGeek website.

WORK IN PROGRESS!!
UPDATE

So this time I have no time to explain how many mepples you need to print in each case. But I expect you to know that!

You can scale the mepples as desired. The print size I use is set to 15mm in the longest dimension (X,Y), proportional for the other and 5mm for Z.

  • animepples-cerdo.stl is the file for a single PIG. Agricola needs 18 pigs. Originally black as savage pigs, but I like more the pink PLA version. :P
  • animepples-trigo.stl is the file for a single WHEAT. Agricola needs 27. I used yellow PLA.
  • animepples-oveja.stl is the file for a single SHEEP. Agricola needs 21. I used white ABS.

More to come as I print them... :)

description.text:
This is a simple macro tube adaptor for a 50mm f/1.7 CHINON manual lens.
As I do not like using plastic parts close to the APS-C sensor, I use a cheap 49mm Macro Reverse Adapter Ring for Sony NEX E-Mount which fits inside the A6000. This piece is screwed inside a 3D printed interface into which is inserted a piece of 45mm pvc tubing.
At the other extremity, there is another 3D printed part fitting the pentax K_mount I get in my CHINON lens

see the video for further details. http://youtu.be/wo4cIPU84s8

This technique can easily be used to adapt any lens even for a non macro tube. It is easy to accurately calibrate the length in order to get a proper infinity focusing. Once calibrated, just glue the pvc in place !

printed in PLA.

PVC ext diameter is 45 mm. Cut a lenght of around 45 mm to get the magnification shown in the video.

just play with the .scad file to adapt dimensions to your PVC tubing.
It is important to get a tight fit between PVC tubing and the 3D printed parts.

Don't forget to paint in black the inner part of the PVC tubing to avoid reflections and straylight.

title: Adjustable filament spool holder vor Vulcanus V1

description.text:
The part is for this amazing printer (Vulcanus V1, CoreXY based): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:821066

I've needed a simple and easy adjustable spool holder for different types of filament and different widths of their spools. So I made this one - it works like charm! To adjust the width for a new spool simply rotate on the M8 nut holder - the part in the middle will move left or right.

What you need:

  • 4x 609zz bearings (9mm inner diameter)
  • 2x smooth rod m6 42cm
  • 1x threaded rod m8 40cm
  • 2x M8 nut
  • 2x M8 stop nut
  • 4x M5 extrusions nuts (the same you've used to build the Vulcanus V1)
  • 4x M5x10mm bolts (the same you've used to build the Vulcanus V1)
  • screw glue (loctite or smiliar)
  • the printed parts (1x left, 1x right, 1x middle, 8x spacer for the bearings, 1x M8 nut holder)

Please see the images how to build and how to attach it

title: Low polygon printable mask with holes for ribbon and a drinking straw
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I remixed this from the Low Polygon Printable Mask for a few reasons:

  • So it would fit my head (by removing the sides)
  • So I could easily attach ribbon to hold it on my head (added side holes)
  • So I can drink with it on (added a vital straw hole in the mouth :) )

No supports are needed - all the overhangs should be gentle enough for most FDM 3D printers.

I have included source (STL) for 3 variations:

  • One with ribbon holes and straw hole
  • One with just the ribbon holes, in case you don't appreciate that Blue Steel look
  • One without any holes - a blank canvas for your own mods

Massive thanks to kongorilla for the original design, and to Gromfrog for making the STL.

I finished my mask with a few post-processing steps:

  • Hot glue gun to fill some minor splitting (though I have since discovered "dremel friction welding" that would have been slightly better)
  • 24hr acetone vapour treatment, though it didn't seem to have an effect, and I ran out of time to try again
  • 1 rather heavy coat of gold spray paint
  • Foam pads inside help the mask sit correctly on my face
  • Attached ribbon ties

I printed ABS on my Pangu i3 with 0.3mm layers at 30mm/sec and no fan, rectilinear (fast) infill at 15%. It took about 6 hours to print.

There is some minor delamination on the sides, under the nose, and across the mouth and eyebrows. I blame the low temperature in my print room, though it could well be a calibration issue with my printer. Because i printed without fan, there are some minor stringy bits inside the mask at the top of the eye slots, where the slope of the overhang was at its greatest on this model.

A small container with a tongue and groove lid that "pops" into place. Expected to be dependent on material, wall thickness, clearances, etc.; this version was printed from PLA with 0.3 mm levels and two shells. OpenSCAD code is included.

title: Pangu i3 z end stop holder

description.text:
This will hold your z end stop firmly in place. I designed this after getting fed up of the included holder occasionally slipping down the z rail.

It attaches to the printer with the existing screw and bolts, so no extra hardware required.

If I were to print this again, I would make it 1cm shorter, as the z axis carriage (that holds the x axis motor) comes within about 1mm of the top.

I printed this in black ABS with 0.3mm layers and 100% infill. At 60mm/s and no fan, it turned out a little sloppy but still completely functional. I have since discovered that a print speed of 30mm/s would have resulted in a much cleaner print!

author: sakana280

description.text:
The thermal shrinking of printed things causes the boarder area to bend. This warping could be greatly reduced by this structure. Therefore most horizontal layers consists of squares. When the isolated squares shrink, it will not bend the hole object. This OpenSCAD Script will generate custom blocks of xyz size of your choice. You should keep in mind the total numbers of elements, because of the increase of calculation time. It is like the cubic crystal structure of Sodalith (#218, P43n).
I made two pictures of a durability test. It works well with 73 kg on top with a piece of wood. But if it breaks apart, then it seems to explode from the high tension inside. Update V2: Optimized the script for a fast preview in Customizer..

Choose the wall thickness according to your printer's nozzle size and the desired stability. If you need bigger values than in the Customizer allowed, you should use OpenSCAD to calculate it. For me it crashed at about 4000 elements.

title: LED strip clip for 20mm 3D printer frames
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These will clip onto your 20mm standard 3D printer struts, like my Taz4. Just clip the LED into them, then clip them onto your printer where you want a little more light. The angled clip keeps the light out of your view.

These fit these 12v LEDs from Banggood.

I mounted one in the center top and another to the center right frame rails. Just provide 12v power source and you are set.

I powered them from the same 12v that runs my Fume Filter thing:929473 so that the lights come on with the fan.

If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

Print two for each light you have.

Make sure to file the surfaces that will clip to both the LED and the 20mm frame. The tolerances are tight and this will help make sure they clip on easily but hold on securely.

remixed_from.author: happynew3d
remixed_from.title: New material for flexy object extrude

title: Printing in Polyurethane Rubber using Fenner Drives' Eagle Orange

description.text:
Following in the footsteps of others, I ordered some 3mm polyurethane belting from Fenner Drives (http://www.fennerdrives.com/non-reinforced-belting/?s=ZnwxNzc5). I went with the Eagle Orange 85, as I felt its softness and color were ideal. I will be posting an account of my experiences with it here. I am printing on a slightly modified Solidoodle 2 using a 0.35mm J-head mounted in Lawsy's MK4 extruder direct drive system using the Repertier Host software and MLaws modified Marlin firmware. Best settings so far (these are what have worked best for me, let me know if you get better results using others):
Temp- 190 C first layer, 180 C others
Speed-Slow, ~20mm/s
Cooling-active fan (not sure if necessary but I had it on)
Bed-Kapton with Hairspray, heating optional
Layer thickness-0.15mm
Extrusion width-0.42mm (0.5 for infill, which I may increase)

6/30/13
-been working with this a bit now, and been having some fun. Printed a suction cup mount for lithopanes (will post it later) as well as a boomerang and some small feet I plan to use for another project. I noticed that at times the extruder is slipping on the filament, as it is very smooth and doesn't allow the teeth to really get a good grip on it. Increasing the tension helped, as well as turning up the temperature a bit. -I also designed a small tag for my tweezers so that they are labeled as mine. Printed alright, although the text was hard to read. 5/23/13
-The first thing I did after receiving the filament was try directly extruding using the stock J-head extruder. Unfortunately I found that the gap between my drive gear and the head tube was too large, and the more flexible filament was prone to bending, resulting in kinks and no extrusion. I added a small tube of PTFE to the top of the head to compensate, and this prevented kinking from occuring.
-For adhesion, I first tried my Kapton heated bed treated with Hairspray without the heater on. Adhesion was excellent so I didn't worry about this.
-Speed was my next issue. Due to the larger diameter of the 3mm filament, and the tendency to string horribly, I found that lower speeds worked best. I will continue to push the speed as I optimize other parameters, but currently ~20mm/s for perimeters works well. Started to get delamination and stringing at higher speeds.
-Next up was temperature calibration. I started with a 2cm test cube, with 2 perimeters and 5 bottom layers with a layer thickness of 0.15mm. I initially started at 215C, but this proved very gooey, so I reduced temperature gradually until I found what I thought was optimum at 190. Final print had many defects early on, and I think there was some degradation at the higher temperature, but as I went lower the quality improved and I was hopeful for a good print.
-Following the Octupus theme of my predecessor, I went with Cute Octopus says Hello (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27053) at 0.15mm with 2 perimeters and 15% infill. I started at 195 for the first layer and 190 for the rest, but quickly noticed a large amount of stringing. To reduce this, I tried decreasing the temperature some more, and found that 180 reduced this somewhat and still resulted in good extrusion. The low infill level with honeycomb produced some nasty internal structure, with lots of stringers inside. I did notice that the flexible nature of the material meant that the upraised arm began to lose some detail as it got taller, so I presume tall thin designs will not print well (not really a surprise), although the slower perimeters went better than the faster infill. I also found that near the end, especially when trying to do solid infill over partial, decreasing the speed even more and temperature to 175C helped. It may be possible to print entirely at this lower temp to produce better results. Final thoughts after first prints:
Finished product has the same feel as a bathtub rubber duck. Would be great for rubber bulbs such as pipette bulbs or rubber tires for model cars.
Top layer if small tends to melt horribly. Turning down temp for last few layers a must. Cooling increase needed?
Stringing is a major issue, even with high retraction settings. Low viscosity of melt means drooling is a given. Minimum temperature for extrusion recommended to help mitigate. 5/23/13 #2
wanted to try a tire out of this rubber, so used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32023 as a test. Printed the tyre part out of polyurethane and was very impressed with the flexibility and feel of it. This was a flat tire, simply providing traction, but I think a puffy tire would be even better. Designing the tire to fit on a rim may be tricky, but not impossible. The printed tire turned out to be super flexible, similar in feel to one of those rubber wristbands, but a little less stretchy. Surface feels like acetone vapor treated ABS. Very nice and shiny. I found that printing at 175 C produced the least stringiness and best quality. I also noticed that due to the low viscosity of the melt, it oozes alot as it is heating up (probably didn't help that I heated it to 200 initially). This led to poor initial extrusion, so to compensate I upped the multiplier to 1.5X until it was extruding well again. Another note of possible interest, this material pulls out of the nozzle very easily, and completely (even pulled out of the tip) at just 100C. Makes for very easy cleaning of the nozzle, and may even be useful for cleaning other gunk out of the nozzle if it clogs. 5/24/13
Added a picture of the finished wheel with tire. Fit was perfect, and nice and tight. Tire was nice and stretchy, so even if the rim was a bit too small it would still fit over no problem. This was just a flat inner rim with a flat tire. No air cushion. This material would probably work just as well or better with cushioned tires, and the ability to custom print treads seems interesting. Rim was printed in black ABS.

description.text: Attaches to a chain saw handle (with a diameter of approx 25mm) to help cut firewood logs at proper length.

See picture for the part in action. With this part, it's a lot easier to cut logs at proper and equal length.

Rotate 90 degrees before printing so the nut pocket faces upwards.

You need an M5 nut and bolt, a thumbwheel ( e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:728871) and a 5mm thick metal rod.
The nut might be a somewhat thight fit in the nut pocket.

Measure 30 cm (or however long you want your logs to be cut), perpendicular to the chainsaw blade, and cut the metal rod at the proper length.

title: Tiny funnel for perfumes, fragrances and other small bottles

description.text:
This funnel is only 42mm in diameter and 55mm long. The nozzle is 20mm long and 6mm in diameter.

It's perfect for transferring liquids such as perfumes/fragrances or facial toner to smaller bottles e. g. for carry-on luggage or travel-size bottles.

If you print this with 0.2 mm layer height, the walls should be only two perimeters wide. A fairly slow printing speed is recommended. You'll not need support material.

Please note that you can use almost any liquid with this funnel if you print with ABS, except acetone-based liquids like nail polish remover etc.

You can make it glossy and smooth by treating it with acetone vapor.

author: Saltymoo

description.text:
I made a plot clock too... Thanks joo! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248009

I had a hard time with a few things, so I documented my process in the instructions. Hopefully these will help someone else.

My modification is really minor, and it looks like there are others that do the same. I created a scad file of the part that connects to the arm servos that fits the single horn that came with my servos and used the following projects in addition to my horn part. I also modified the ino file to use some different constants that made it easier for me during the calibration process. See the instructions for more on this.

  1. 3d printable parts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:250204
  2. Expo marker arm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:261999
  3. Battery holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900

Video of it in action:
https://goo.gl/photos/qACTKfDJhuQvSEaRA

Printing

  1. Print the servohorn.stl (x2)
  2. Print all but the servo arms and arm that holds the marker from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:250204
  3. Print the Expo parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:261999
  4. Optionally print the battery holder (in ABS!) from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900 and wire it for series operation. If you don't do this, you will need a power supply for your arduino that has sufficient ampherage to drive all 3 servos. My USB port was not enough to power the servos, and it took a while to figure out why it would start to move, then restart.

Electronics Assembly

  1. I created a servo header complex by soldering (sloppily, don't judge!) 4 x 3-pin headers together with some wire (see picture), but you could also use a breadboard. The servo's red and brown or black go to +5V and GND. Each servo's yellow wire goes to it's pin
    That is really all you need to do for the sample clock. A real time clock would be a good thing, or you can look at some of the other plotclock mods out there for other ideas (serial time, drawing, etc)

Mechanical Assembly

  1. Put the printed parts of the base together and sand / file as appropriate to get them to fit together. They should be snug. Use Joo's skp file as a guide for where parts go.
  2. use a 3mm drill bit or file to make sure that the arm part holes all have enough give to allow them to move freely with M3 bolts attached.
  3. attach the servo horns to my part with a wire or small screw
  4. attach the servo horn to the lifter servo and make sure it rotates from basically flat toward the other servos up to 90 degrees.
  5. attach the driving arm for the lifter servo to the horn with a small screw.
  6. attach all the arms to one another (refer to all the pictures there are on these plot clocks. It is especially important with the expo marker to make sure the expo arm is on the bottom side so the marker can reach the drawing surface.
  7. I used self-locking nuts to fasten the bolts so that they won't work off while the arms are moving.
  8. rotate the arm servos by hand counter-clockwise to the end stop.
  9. attach the arm parts with the left arm facing left 100 degrees (counter clockwise of flat) and the right arm facing straight up. don't screw them on until you do the calibration.
  10. I did not put in the clip for the pen/eraser head, since it does not quite fit. I will upload a new clip when I get one that works for me.
  11. Use a rubber band or elastic string to attach a paper towel or other soft eraser like material to the expo pen holder. Trim anything that comes up over the sides so the pen won't catch on anything.

Calibration

  1. manually position the arms so that the left arm is roughly horizontal and the right arm is vertical and the bottom servo so the arms are well above the surface
  2. upload the ino file to the arduino (with calibration uncommented).
  3. What you should see is that the two arms move back and forth.

You will adjust some numbers in the ino file to get these arms to move correctly, then you will turn off calibration and adjust some more.

The lines you will be adjusting are:

#define SERVOFAKTORLEFT xxx
#define SERVOFAKTORRIGHT xxx
#define SERVOLEFTNULL xxx
#define SERVORIGHTNULL xxx
#define LIFT0 xxx
#define LIFT1 xxx
#define LIFT2 xxx

Here is what mine looks like during calibration: https://goo.gl/photos/JceryoG6WuWsPQMy6

  • If you increase the LIFTx numbers, the arms should get closer to the platform.
  • if you increase the SERVOFAKTORxxx numbers, a bigger angle will be used in the arms
  • if you increase the SERVOXXXNULL numbers, the point at which the servos stop changes

I just played around with these numbers, then uploaded to see the results. Once you are happy with these, comment out the CALIBRATION line and upload again.

At this point, you should see the arm go up to the upper right, wipe back and forth to "erase", then draw the canned time "19:38" from the hardcoded numbers in the ino file. It will repeat this once per minute, adding a minute to the time until you stop it. This is where you can adjust the LIFTx numbers and get the pen to come down right and clar the top of the holder just right.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3Y2K4GciJGQ
all the parts connect

Here is something useful if you still live in the 21st century and still use Cash for your transactions --> 3D Printed Counterfeit Money detector and Torch..

Make your own using a couple of Ultraviolet LED’s a coin cell battery and 3D print the parts, which fits nice and snug in your Wallet/Purse.

The two 3D printed the parts are about 4 credit cards thick and double up as a torch which you can use to protect yourself tripping over things in the dark.

Watch the short video at( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUXx4JigSGU ) for the direction on how to use the Portable Counterfeit Money detectors and torch.Basically the 3D printed base has 3 slots

-one to store the coin cell battery when it is not being used

  • second slot on the left has 2 UV LEDs where you will have to insert the coin cell battery
    -third slot on the right which has a bright white LED which lights up when the battery is inserted and acts as a torch

Here are the electronic components you'll need to complete the build.

  • 2 Ultraviolet LED’s(https://www.adafruit.com/products/1793)
  • 1 Super Bright LED.(https://www.adafruit.com/products/754).
  • Coin cell battery - CR2302(http://www.adafruit.com/product/654)

In addition you'll need super glue and a set of Pliers to put all the components and 3D Printed parts together.. I've added a few making pictures above..

For step by step instruction refer to
http://www.instructables.com/id/DIY-Portable-Counterfeit-Money-detector-and-Torch/

This is an improved version of my " The flying Thingummies "
The Thingummies are little creatures. They are active and sociable.
Here they catch the wind and form an original weathercock, made by independent elements or by connected elements to form a fair .
Put it in your garden or in your balcony and cheer them up !
This thing is very easy to make and to put in place, see the instructions.
Have a look to other Thingummies in my collection " The Thingummies "

This thing is composed by three independent elements, about 15 cm long, 22 cm wide ( max ) and and 5 mm high.
They have two little rings which allow them to rotate around a thread ( nylon thread, one or more, spring or other . ).
You have just to thread the elements, starting from the upper one, and to make some knots under the lower ring of each element,
in order to fix the level.
You can also form a sort of fair, connecting three elements by a thread , through the little holes in the center of each element. ( The rings are designed to allow the connection ).
Finally you have to fix the thread up and down. Take care of your safety when you make it !

Floating vessel designed to increase its overall buoyancy as the applied load is increased.

Bottom slides up inside Top and is prevented from falling out under excess load by Lock. The inside of Top is a hollow air pocket, lowering the density of the overall vessel.

The base of Bottom is hollow to increase its buoyancy so it doesn't fall all the way to Lock as soon as it's put in water.

When the whole assembly is put into water, the tubes on the sides allow water to fill inside the top (allowing air to escape so water can enter), up until it reaches the top rim of Bottom. This allows the vessel to sink slightly rather than float entirely above water, increasing stability.

As weight is added to the vessel, Bottom will be pulled down but the four holes in the top of Top will allow air to enter into Top, expanding its air pocket and, therefore, decreasing overall density of the vessel even further.

...I hope it works :)

A model of the London red phone booths.

This will make a nice little space waster on your desk at home or at work! Or to save up to go and see the world!

Please read the instructions for more information about this project.

Thanks for checking out this thing!

Franciscozapski has kindly printed this to show that it is indeed printable.

Make sure you select the correct file to print!

A friend of mine has agreed to print this, but I don't know when he'll be able to. When it is done, I'll post the pics of the printed booth!

This model stands roughly 15cm tall (~5.9' inches) and I recommend printing it at full scale to preserve the detail.

I decided to do this project because I think the red phone booths of London are a special landmark that everyone will know about. Also, I think they look really cool.

I used stock images of the phone booths to gauge the relative sizes of all the components, then took to work recreating them with some software.
I also chose a scale to ensure that this object can be printed without any further assembly, although I decided to add a version that can be assembled (with a hinged door).

This model was created in AutoCAD, although I am still quite a novice at the software. This is also a great learning experience for me.

Phase 1 (18/07/2015):

The very first upload. This is simple the box shape with some indented windows for some added detail. I'm currently occupied with other commitments, so I couldn't do a very detailed piece initially.

NB: This design is currently a solid block! So don't print it unless you feel like wasting a lot of precious filament.

For the next update I plan to add some edge detail, and address the solidness of the object, which will make it more print-friendly.

Phase 2 (20/07/2015):

I made some time to get a little bit of work done on the model. Changes conveniently summarised for your reading pleasure:
• Added "Telephone" text
• Added more detail to the roof
• Added a base
• Made it hollow

Yes, that's right! The booth is now hollow on the inside and should therefore be more economical to print. Stay posted for phase 3, where I plan to add extra detail and properly lay out the roof!

Phase 3 (24/07/2015):

A hectic week! I redesigned the entire roof of the booth, which was quite tricky. I still haven't gotten to the result I want, but this will have to suffice for now. Otherwise, not much has changed. A quick update on what has:
• Redesigned roof
• Added some detail to the back of the booth

The detail at the back will probably change as well, due to it not lining up with the windows... It's just a preliminary design for the next release.

Stay tuned for the next update where I plan to add detail to all sides of the booth.

Phase 4 (28/07/2015):

I haven't been getting a lot of time to work on the model but I did manage to do the following:
• Redesigned roof (again) [There was a little piece bothering me]
• Redid detail at the back of the booth
• Added detail to all sides (including a handle)
• Completely hollow

Now, I don't know what the support implications will be of making this thing hollow, but according to this site it should be printable on a MakerBot Replicator.

I still do plan to make some changes to this model. Perhaps a version that prints in pieces and requires assembly to save material (from supports). I have a few surprises planned for this design, though. So keep watching!

Phase 5 (01/08/2015):

With the weekend comes the following small adjustment:
• Added a phone

What is a phone booth without a phone? I think the next update will be the final one, which will consist of a dismantled version that requires assembly, as well as a surprise...

Phase 6 (09/08/2015):

This is the final design! I have been so extremely busy with other work that I almost forgot about the deadline. With this final version comes the following changes:
• Now made to assemble
• The door has (supposedly) working hinges!
• A coin bank version is available

Thanks for checking out this thing. If you want to download the assembly version, download the 2 files that have "assembly" in the title. If you want to coin bank, download the file with that says "coinholder" in the title.

I'll update this page one last time in the future with a printed version of the booth.

description.text: You can make Craftbot a lot quieter by installing dampers on stepper motors and putting it on flexible legs. Here are two simple designs, you will be surprised by the results :)

The stepper motor dampers are simple flexible washers.
First print out 24 pieces using a FLEXIBLE filament (Filaflex worked well for me, but others should too). If you never printed with Filaflex before: 230 °C, cold bed and LOW speed, max 20 mm/s. Print quality is not very important for this application.
After printing, get some wide metal washers for 3 mm screws.
Install the dampers as follows - unscrew all four screws on a stepper motor, put 4 dampers on the motor, push the motor against the sheet metal, put one damper on the hole in the sheet metal, put a washer on top of it and insert the screw, screw it in, but don't tighten. Do the same with the three remaining screws. Use a flat screwdriver to tighten the belt properly and tighten the front two screws. Remove the flat screwdriver, tighten the back two screws and check the two front ones again. Use a bit of glue/paint to secure screws against unscrewing. Repeat for the remaining two servos. Remember, damping only works if there is a damper between the motor and the sheet metal below AND there a damper between the sheet metal and the washer+screw on top.

Legs are really simple - just print 4 of them using a flexible filament, get 4 wood screws (4 x 25 mm), remove the old legs and screw the legs in place. The two legs on the back side can only be screwed in with the back plate removed.

This flotation device was created to be stable and have a large weight capacity. The pontoons with wine corks add stability and increase the weight capacity but are not necessary. Since the wine corks have have a lower density than the PLA filament and water then they greatly add to the weight capacity.

Flotation capability:
Without pontoons: 20 quarters, approximately 113.4 grams
With pontoons but not wine corks: 24 quarters, approximately 136.08 grams
With pontoons and wine works: 32 quarters, approximately 181.44 grams

The floating device consists of 1 base part and 6 identical cork pontoon pieces as well as 6 wine corks that assist in the flotation process. The corks are made with a rectangular extrusion that fits nicely into the base for a stable connection.

Printing specs:
Base - shell thickness 0.8 mm, fill density 20%
Pontoons - shell thickness 0.8 mm, fill density 0%, no solid bottom infill.

title: Wall mount for a Sony home theater speaker.

description.text: Wall and corner mounts for Sony SS-MSP2 home theater speakers... but could work for similar sized speakers.

I designed this using123D Design (An extruded series of sketches). Just print what you need and bolt the parts together with some short pieces of threaded rod.  These speakers have a rear mounting hole that fits short M5 bolts. The slot on the piece to which the speaker connects is "large" so you will want to use a washer.

comments.text: Hi Peter!
comments.author: Jvancsik

comments.text: I used ABS and have the speakers in a room that doesn't get a whole lot of sunlight so I can't give too much detail on heat.  But I have just posted a few pics to show how they look almost 3 years later.   There is some 'sagging' on the corner mounts because of the weight of the speakers and the long platform ( its kinda like a diving board) but the flat wall mounts haven't shown any noticeable changes other than discoloring over time.

description.text:
Rather than just designing a boat -we created a modular playset for anyone to create their own design and explore the properties of buoyancy. Let your child tinker, make from their imaginations, and actually LEARN with Maker Jr.!
In this set, your child can learn about buoyancy and learn to make a boat that floats! The

Thanks to MakerBot for supporting the #MakeItFloat challenge!

PLA from MakerFront: http://www.makerfront.com/

The example raft shown here is "the hexagon raft". It will support three US quarters; but this is a modular play set, so if you make your own raft, post a make and explore the properties of buoyancy. :D

Feel free to customize the design to fit your style. PLEASE share your makes and remixes!

Enjoy the first Maker Jr. play set!

This play-set was designed in 123d design by a 11 year old maker.
Printed at 0.3mm layer height.

parts required for the example hexagon raft:
-4x small hexagon platforms
-2x air capsules
-2x foam capsules
-4x cube units
-4x peg units
-1x foam sponge
and probably a towel.

However, to make the complete set you need (this may change):

-50x cube units
-75x peg units
-16x foam capsules
-16x air capsules
-10x small hexagon platforms
-10x small square platforms
-5x large hexagon platforms
-5x large square platforms
-3x octagon platforms
-1x Maker Jr. key chain
-1x foam sponge

description.text:
This is a head-base that can be used to build a puppet-, plushie-, robot- or even a fursuit-head. Fake fur can be glued on.

It is scaled for hand-puppet size and fits my hand perfectly. If you want to use it for a costume you should scale it to at least 23cm width. I printed this model in PLA.

The lower jaw is included - I printed everything without support.

comments.text: This is going to be awesome for my dream costume project: Chocobo rider!!!
comments.author: sailorcrafty

comments.text: Also can you please tell me the length of the original finished head? It will save me some time trying to scale each piece for my project.
comments.author: sailorcrafty

comments.text: The head has three parts - if you print the parts without rescaling the assembled head should be about 208 mm long. That's the size for a 1m tall hand-puppet. It is currently sized to have enough room for a hand with glove-size S-M inside the beak. For a wearable costume, I usually adjust the width of the head to a minimum of 230mm - I have a small head.

title: Root shield for aquaponics system. Prevents fish from eating roots.

description.text:
This is a root shield for pots in an aquaponic system. We had problems with fish eating the roots of plants, specifically basil plants. This will guard the roots against the fish up to a length of about 30cm. The unit itself is a bit longer than 30cm. The inner diameter at the narrowest part is about 5.9cm, if you're wondering what pots it fits.

The 3dm file, and rootshield2.stl are the same. I designed the first one and exported it to STL but the computer overheated and shut off before I saved the 3dm.

Released through my company Northern Layers: http://northernlayers.com
It should simply be a compression or friction fit.

comments.text: I'm curious how the fish had access to the roots. Do you have fish in your DWC?

The aim of the enclosed project is to have a fish able to fload as well as able to swim simulating the real motion of a fish.

In addition, the project also includes a floating boat, with a fisherman on it, that is attached to the floating fish by means of a nylon thin cable.

Hard disk motor for swinging away the tail of the fish:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GK4Ald8OjaI

RC fish movement:

  1. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u49H3aTLoL0
  2. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpD2i3U2qro
  3. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Y2SAVFL2SU
  4. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Il6UGOEsk60
  5. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kjLfjPY7I_g
  6. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9fJFESiL9Yg

Instructions

Part n. 1 (printing all pieces)

All stl files are printed in PLA with two shells at 0.26mm layer height, for some of tham suopport materials are needed .

The boat is printed with two shells in the spiralize way to increase the weight that can be loaded.

The body is printed at 10% infill, while the head is printed at 15% infill and fins are printed at 40% infill.

In order to do not let the water to get into the fish, some holes have been filled with hot glue.

Part n. 2 (assembling the printed pieces)

Take the caudal fin and place three thin nylon cables (about 1 m each) in the three holes. Then, there will be three cables on each side of the caudal fin. They are used to make all tail to bend right and left.
Each set of three cables will then passed into the other four pieces of the fish body.
Place, in those pieces where a pass-through hole is present, one small piece of lead at the bottom part.
Place a 6 mm tube at the center of all the pieces in order to make the pieces to stay in place.
Each piece of the fish body stays separated (about 6 mm distance) from the adiacent ones by mean of small metal springs. The springs have to be placed in the grooves that are present on each piece.
I have used the electronics and the motor of a rc-car. In the bigger piece of the fish body two big grooves are present. They allocate the battery and the electronic board. The antenna (connected to the board) has to go out of the piece through the proper hole.

Take the piece that join the tail and the head (testa_parte_3_3.stl).
The end part of the 6 mm tube has to be connected to it in order to block the tube.

Take the two pieces of the head. In the bottom part (testa_parte_2_3.stl) the servomotor has to be placed. I used some glue in order to take it in position.
Two small metal bars are connected to the servo motor. The bars are long enough to exit the head (from the holes that are present in the stl file) and are then connected to the two lateral fins.
The six nylon thin cables have to be twisted and then firmly blocked to the piece. Use the two grooves that are present in the stl file.
Take the gear and connect it to the axes of the servomotor. Place a 5 mm screw in the external hole of the gear.
Use three screws to join the two pieces of the head.
The two pieces of the head have to be connected to the piece that join the tail and the head by means of a metal ball bearing and two 4 mm passing through screws.

Take the two head covers (I uploaded the right piece only. To have the left one make the mirror of the first one) and place on the fish head. Use four screws to join the two part firmly.
Take the later fins and join them to the head covers by means of two 2 mm screws.
Connect the metal bars of the servo motor to the lateral fins using hot glue.

Take the dorsal fin and connect it to the head covers using hot glue.

Finally, take the external cover (cover_corpo_flessibile.stl) and join it to the fish body by a bit of hot glue. These two parts have to be printed using flexible filament.

I apologize because some photos do not match the file stl loaded because I did not have time to print out the improved version of a few parts.

This bait holder keeps ant bait (made with peanut butter and Borax) enclosed and out of the way. Ants are attracted to the peanut/Borax mix and take it back to the nest to be digested for the colony, killing the nest.

1. Print the bait holders
  2. Mix peanut butter with borax
  3. Place a small amount of mixture on the middle of the base.
  4. Snap the cap onto the base risers (there will be a small gap between the base and the cap)
  5. Leave the bait holder where you see ants.

This does not trap ants, ants are attracted to the peanut butter and take it with the borax back to the nest where the borax kills the colony.
